The commonly sold burger patty presses are too small (at least the ones in germany).
So i designed a patty press for the standard 120mm Burger Buns. The inner diameter of the press is 130mm, which results in a approx. 120mm ready grilled patty.

Update: Re-uploaded STL files because resolution was much too low. Sorry

K3D homemade

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

30%

Notes:

Printed with a 0.4mm nozzle and 3 outlines.
I printed it in grey ABS because it withstands higher temperatures while cleaning and i could treat the press with acetone vapor to make it absolutely watertight. The surface also because nice flat and shiny, but acetone treatment is not absolutely necessary. I had a prototype doing it's job for 2 month and is was watertight too.

print_settings.Notes:: This is a somewhat easy print. No falsework required. But, depending on your bed adhesion, some anti-warping measure may be necessary. A brim instead of a raft may do the trick.

description.text:
A hook to hold up the x axis assembly of a GeeTech i3 pro C printer. Use a pair.

An extra benefit of an anti z-wobble part is that it allows you to pull up the whole x axis assembly. I use this to clean the nozzle, change filaments, or just clean the build plate.

Center the x axis. Use both hands. Grab the left and right of the top x axis rod with the round hooks from behind, pull up and hook the square parts over the acrylic frame, to the left and right of the display.

This might work for other printers with a similar layout, but probably not as well when the distances and sizes aren’t exactly the same.

There are now two styles, one that goes to the front of the frame, and one that hooks over the back of the frame. That one is a bit more cumbersome, but it works when you have an x axis cable chain installed.

Caveat

This requires an anti z-wobble part. Without it, when pulling on the rods you’ll lift the whole printer.

Caveat 2

Remember to let the assembly down again before you start a print. I mention this because this might be something that people might forget. It totally hasn’t happened to me, like, a dozen times. Of course not.

Printer:

GeeeTech i3 pro C

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

300 µm

Infill:

15 %

Notes:

This is a somewhat easy print. No falsework required. But, depending on your bed adhesion, some anti-warping measure may be necessary. A brim instead of a raft may do the trick.

There is some design history available at my github repo.

I have done this in different lengths. I usually use only the longest, the 120 mm version. The other pair i have printed is the 75 mm version.

After i added a cable chain, i had to redesign this so it goes behind the frame

I have included the FreeCAD files. The sizes can be changed in the spreadsheet.

author: tituspullus

description.text: Rendered from a ridiculously detailed Lidar dataset available at http://opentopo.sdsc.edu/. I had to severely decimate the data to even get it onto my software. This is the highest resolution mesh I could make with all of Half Dome in it. The resolution may be overkill for current printers, but you can always dump some if you need to. You can watch my tutorial video at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t4-ICkvyJv0 Be sure to check out the ridge where the cableway climbs up. It clearly shows just how steep it is. I also posted a version which crops at the base of the NW face so you can save time and materials if you like. This thing was featured on the 3D Printing Today podcast available on iTunes, Stitcher radio or direct from the source at http://threedprintingtoday.libsyn.com/

description.text:
These models are the creative work of Mansour Khaleqi, Yvo Kipping, Pieter van Zelst and Suzanne Spiering. They are an attempt at prolonging the life of Bugaboo strollers in the frame of the Endless Objects project: by having them repaired in makerspaces using the information from the producer/OEM/brand.

Some of the models are better suited for FDM printing and some are better suited for SLS. You can figure out which is which. A repair guide is published online so you can see how to retrofit the parts on your Bugaboo.

title: Filament Guides for the Anet A8 in 6 variations (0°, 45°, 90°) Vertical and Horizontal
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Just another set of filament guides for the Anet A8. Filament diameter 1.75mm

Since I found none with the desired angles, I just designed them my own based on the design of papinist (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1764285)

There are 6 files for the angles 90°, 45° and 0° with a vertical and a horizontal version for each.

If you like it, you may also check out my other Anet A8 and 3d printing things:

  • Customizeable Cooling Fan Blades
  • Anet A8 - Original X Axis Mounts V2
  • Linear Bushing / Bearing - LM8UU - IGUS like - with mount
  • Spoolhoder tube to lower rotational resistance (requires two axle bearings)
  • Cable Clip (Anet like)
  • Improved Customizeable Anet A8 E3Dv6 Mount with 40mm Fan Mount

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used PLA as material for the guides, but it should also work with other materials.

All variations need about 2m of 1.75mm filament.

The 90° and 45° horizontal versions can be printed without support, whilst their vertical versions require support structures.

The 0° ones might as well be printed laying down, but then supports are necessarry. The way they are in the file, both are printable without supports if you add a raft to improve adhesion.
I have been using Blender before and since I liked the design of the filament guide this ones are based on, I basically just redesigned them in Blender.

title: LWC tactical T.H.E.R.M.A.L "budget"  imager WIP
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
STOP! Do not download yet, this is a work in progress.
Performance and real life usage for airsoft is not yet tested and far from completion.
This could remain a prototype and never be finished.
The components for this build are not cheap, I still try to make it as easy and cheap as possible. ( talking about 250€ max.)
Of course this build bares the risk of breaking the thermal sensor and flushing a lot of money down the drain. So keep in mind that there is no guarantee from my side that this thing is going to work like you would expect it to.

UPDATE 14.12.2017
Big Price drop on the thermal imager, updated the link in the description!! ( 127€)

UPDATE 07.12.2017

Please dont get mad at me when there wont be any updates soon, I have to wait for the lenses to arrive which will take from 2 up to 4 weeks with ease. Cannot afford buying those kind of lenses locally, way to expensive ;)

UPDATE 05.12.2017

Today I added 2 parts for focusing with the new lens. Original the fixed focus is set to 50cm which makes everything over that blurry like hell, with a adjustable focus this should result in much better picture quality! Hopefully this works ;)

Shot counter?! peace of cake. Laser rangefinder?! easy peasy. Night vision!? oh come on you can do better than that! .......Thermal imager?? NOW we are talking.
Incredible expensive, costing a fortune and those you can buy for "cheap" are devices you have to plug to your phone, but who wants to risk getting his phone shot?!

What I am trying here is to build a thermal imager with a range of about 50 meters ( or maybe more, tests will show) that doesnt cost much more than up to 250€ ( of course this is also not guaranteed)

The heart of the Thermal imager is relatively cheap Chinese Thermal imager that cost me about 160€ without tax and delivery. It uses a hybrid system of a 60x60 pixel thermal image processor and a common 1.3 megapixel camera.

I already have a working prototype that uses a simple convex lense ( like used in google cardboard) so you can turn a simple handheld device in a " close to eye" device which with you wont miss the slightest change of color on the display if a thermal source comes up to the sensors field of view).

The detection range for now is somewhere from 20 to 25 meters ( person in winter clothes)
This Result was tested with temperatures around 0° Celsius.

I purchased a special lense with much bigger surface then the original germanium coated small lense that should catch a lot more thermal radiation then the original. Luckily the chinese sensor is easy to open up with almost no hassle at all. With a focal length of 15mm I also should get some pretty good zoom on that.

This is a very delicate task and I have no Idea if I can pull this off the way I want it to work.
Time and tests will show.

The fresnel lens will be detachable so you can use the Thermal imager in common "household" modus. How this will work with the bigger lens is still standing in the stars as I am actually waiting for it to arrive. ( a 13mm in diameter metal lens that costs around 40 including shipping€ O.o)

Again, this Mod could remain a never " commercially" available product here on thingiverse. Still, thermal imager are very very cool but also very very pricy, even this relatively cheap mod. It probably would be better to simply buy a Seek thermal camera for iphone or android. ( Flir not so much because the suck! seriously I tried to contact them as I wanted to realize this project with a lepton sensor but as soon they realized I am no big money business man they just ignored me, completely. Great work greedy dumboos :/ A simple no would have been enough >:(

Stay tuned for further upgrades on this Project ;)

Things you need for this Build:

Thermal imager:
https://de.aliexpress.com/item/HT-02D-Handheld-W-rmebildkamera-Infrarot-thermometer-IR-W-rmebildkamera-thermometre-infra-termometro-infravermelho/32833904540.html?
( you should not pay more than 130€ wait for some special sales ) If the price is to high look a few hours later! they constantly change the price to put some pressure on you to finally buy XD )

Fresnel lens:

https://de.aliexpress.com/item/2pcs-lot-25mm-x-45mm-BiConvex-Lens-for-Google-Cardboard-DIY-3D-VR-Glasses-High-quality/32685561574.html

Thermal Imager Germanium and Zinc Selenid lens: ( NOT YET TESTED!!!)

https://www.ebay.de/itm/Germanium-Lens-PCX-Thorlabs-LA9410-F-1-2-Dia-f-15-mm-IR-AR-8-12-%C2%B5m-CO2-Laser/111231059741?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649

description.text:
This is an adaptor to use on the Electric Speedloader from Team Vanguard. It allows users to fill there PTW mags with more ease and allows them to discharge them before each fill or when storing them.

Pay special attention when using a mag with an loose follower, they can fall out during discharging. We always recommend using a fixed follower.
There are many different PTW mag's on the market, not all will work as good as others.

All feedback is welcome

title: Prusa i3 MK2 - Linear Advance Calibration

description.text:
Two testfiles that allow you to callibrate Linear Advance for your Prusa i3 MK2 3D-Printer.

For using Linear Advance you will need the so calles "K-Factor", deppending on your Material the needed factor will be between 0 and 100. For PLA good values are between 35 and 50.

The test files will creates a few lines in ascending order. Both files start with a K value of 0 and then a step size of 5 or 10 (depending on the used file). The whole test only works with the the most recent firmware, PLA and is only tested for i3 MK2(S) 3D-Printers.

For me a K-Value of 40 seems to be the best for PLA.

A more detailed Instruction in Linear Advance and the most recent Firmware-Update for the Prusa i3 is available at our website (German only): https://3druck.com/diy/praxisbericht-firmware-update-und-linear-advance-beim-prusa-i3-mk2s-4765396/

For further testing there is also a simple 20mm cube included. A pictures showes the difference between the cube with Linear Advance (green, K=40) and without Linear Advance (red, K=0).

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

description.text:
I designed these chargers because my old nitecore stopped charging one side. You will need to buy the TP4056 board from amazon or ebay. I got mine here. You will also need some thin wire that will fit in the grooves on the bottom, a few standard paperclips and 8 male header pins.

Bend the paperclips like I show in the pictures. Notice I leave one leg longer than the other. Slide the paperclips into their slots. Bend the longer leg towards the other leg until they touch and trim the excess. This will be your solder point. Solder one end of the wire to the paperclip and the other end to the short side of the header pin. Then slide the header pin into the correct hole. Repeat with all other solder connections. Note that the top slots are for connecting the two boards together and will just have a header pin soldered to both sides of the wire. Finally place the boards with the pins sticking through the holes in the boards and solder the pins to the boards.

The TP4056 can deliver a max of 1 amp per board. This means that if you want to fully use it's capability, Use a 2 amp charger.

JanM created a lid for the 18650 charger board here.

title: Toroid Helpers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Many hams "wind their own": inductors using toroids and wire.
One of the challenges in doing this (besides counting ;) is getting the wire tight and nice around the toroid. For some of the most common toroid sizes (68, 80 and 94) I have designed these little helpers. Once fastened in a vise they press the wire towards the inside of the toroid (see picture above) and hold the toroid in place for you to straighten out the wire on the outside.

If you are using enameled copper wire it might be a good idea to wrap some teflon strip around the helpers like I did in order to protect the coating.

title: Turbine of a vacuum cleaner "Kenwood Cyclonic Jet Stream VAC" - Replacement

description.text:
This replacement part was created for a damaged turbine of vacuum cleaner. The problem is how to insert the copper core into the part which shall be embedded by plastic. Finally, the copper core was taken out from the existing turbine by breaking it. Then, the coppper core was freezed in low temperature a while before hammering to the PLA printed turbine which was sunk in a heat water bath. Finally, a littel deformed in its shape.

For anyone without 3D-printer, I would like to print it one out for free. You are only required to sent me the postal fees. So, please free to contact me at [email protected]

title: Case for a GPS Breakout in Sketchup (how to make simple cases for your projects)

description.text:
Time ago I searched a lot for tutorials or manuals how to make cases for projects. I had a LCD+touch assembly with 3 layers of PCBs and making the case was very hard for me (keeping all the 'virtual' positions of everything of the model) so I gave up that time. After I while I found that making a cuboid representation of your internals really help into making the case! any complex project can be represented by simple shapes and you just make the case on top!
Here is the video for the process of making this case: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=22wSBw6W1uI (5 min video, 47 mins in real time)
About the module:
This is just a cheap GPS module from ebay, GTPA010. The datasheet describes 2 interfaces http://screencast.com/t/teY5OC5N9ry, but I bundled both in this board.

1) Get a caliper and something to take notes
2) Find biggest parts and split them mentally in cuboids, the less cuboids, the better.
3) Keep one point of your object as reference (one point that will touch the case is nice)
4) All the connectors, jacks, plugs and parts that will be accessible from outside, should pop from the internal representation
5) Screw holes also will pop as cilinders from your internal model, remember to use the point of reference to make all the positions match with the case
6) Componentize all the parts as a minimum of 2 components (internal+shell). In this case I am using 2 shells
7) Draw the shell using the internal model as your reference for everything, it is really easy thanks to the simplified internal model!
8) Duplicate your model with the shell components opened and make final touches! Check the assembled copy you left often to keep the consistency
9) Print it!

description.text: Warning: The cover is as of yet untested. Tell me in the comments if it needs to be adjusted. This is a drop-in replacement for the monoprice mini select extruder arm and cover. I modified it in Onshape, and the bearing from the MP Select Mini fits snugly. If you had to replace parts other than the arm or cover of the extruder, Makerbot's other parts should fit fine. I can't find any dimensional differences between my part and the original, but your experience may vary. Tell me if it works in the comments! doesn't seem to have any issues with it but if you do end up with problems, download the "fixed" version and try that. I also added a file with both the cap and the arm.

title: Artificial Christmas Tree to Live Christmas Tree base/stand adapters
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The family Christmas Tree has been passed down to us. Unfortunately we did not get the base for it so we had to go out and see if we could purchase one. The only one that wally world had at the time was this live tree base that would not work for our artificial tree.... without some kind of adapter. Enter the Artificial Christmas Tree to Live Christmas Tree base/stand adapters.

Printing instructions:
Infill 25% or more, objects print fine without any other special settings, support or adhesion required.

Usage Instructions:
The lower adapter is placed in the bottom of the base/stand with the concave bowl facing up to hold the bottom of the tree, and the rectangular arm grooves facing down. Try to align the bottom grooves to rest on the upward facing spikes in the base.
The upper adapter is threaded around the metal post of the artificial Christmas tree and aligned with the base/stand bolts which are then screwed into the adapter until firm and straight.

If the adapters do not fit snugly and securely in your application, please do not use. I am not responsible for any damage caused by use of these objects, use at your own risk. Feel free to contact me if alterations are needed. Feedback welcome.

print_settings.Notes:: Traditionally snakes comes with pieces of alternating colours

title: Magic Snake (Rubik's Snake)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The classic Rubik's snake (Magic Snake) from the 80's!

For those who don't know how it works: it is possible to rotate each segment relative to the other one at 90° intervals. The idea is to "fold" the snake onto itself, creating complex figures.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30

Notes:

Print the pieces on their wide face (the hypotenuse of the triangle).

You will need to print one head, one tail and as many body pieces as you like, although the snake will work best if you use an even number of pieces (24 works very well, being divisible by 2, 3, 4, 6, 8 and 12).

Traditionally snakes comes with pieces of alternating colours (there are some nifty effects that can be achieved with this, when folding the snake.

The pieces have their own support built-in. It's just a tiny column supporting the pin (male connector). The surface where the support touches the piece won't be visible once the snake is assembled, so - provided the cut is flush - you don't need to obsess over leftover marks.

My wife bought this toy for one of our kids, but the toy broke within minutes (it was kept together by a plastic wire passing through all the pieces), so I built a new one.

I knew the toy under the name "Magic Snake" so I initially did not find a ready-made model, but if you search for "Rubik's snake" you will find several other designs alternative to mine.
This is one of my very first designs, any feedback on how to improve is very welcome! :)

title: Actobotics Mount for Moto G4 Play (Team 8706)

description.text: This is a mount for the Moto G4 Play that I designed for my FTC team (Team 8706) for the 2017-2018 season. We have already used it in competition and it has given us no problems thus far. It was designed with Viewphoria in mind. It only takes up the bottom half of the phone and leaves both the front and back cameras exposed. The thickness of the compartment for the phone is larger than the actual thickness of the phone intentionally. It is intended that you put a springy object (such as a folded index card) in that space so that the phone is not either being compressed or permitted to rattle around because of the risk of damaging the phone or the mount. I hope that this mount is useful to you and good luck in your season this year.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator Mini

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

The mount is designed to align with the actobotics hole pattern. We fastened it to the robot using Tetrix screws, but any screw that works with actobotics parts and will fit in the holes on the mount will do. After you install the mount and slide the phone in, fold up an index card and use it to fill the space between the phone and the back of the case.

description.text:
This is a mashup of the "Evolution of the Men's Ring" thing with the "Lego Compatible Disc Button" thing, and a sort of cousin to the "Ring-a-thing" LEGO attachment.
Due to the wonders of OpenSCAD, I modified the LEGO Disc to be filled in, then aligned and combined it to the face of the ring. Voila!

Print out and enjoy! You might have to fiddle with some print settings to get the studs to fit snugly with other LEGO pieces.
I also aligned this ring to be printed studs-down, which caused a little bit of overhang issues. Overall, PLA seems to handle that sort of thing a little better than ABS, but your printage may vary.

print_settings.Notes:: As mentioned, if you pause the print at 2mm in height you can print the last bit of his nose in a different colour.

description.text:
tone001's Christmas Reindeer kit Card was almost perfect in every way. However, I was having a few issues:

  1. Lifting from the bed - I think this was mainly due to my room being so cold and the fact I use blue painters tape without a heated bed, but I have added some 'mouse-ears' to the design and would recommend printing at a diagonal across the print bed if you can (see image)
  2. Post print assembling blues - after struggling to assemble a printed stag (and breaking a few antlers in the process), I decided to tweak the size of the holes so that it was easier to put together. This does mean the final assembled stag is a little looser than the original design, but it should hold together or it can be secured with some glue.

As I was Tinkering with the file I couldn't resist increasing the height of the nose so that we could have a red nosed reindeer! If you pause the print at 2mm in height and change your filament colour to red, it will print the last 0.5mm of your print just on the nose.

Maybe I should change the name to Christmas Rudolph Card Kit....

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

As mentioned, if you pause the print at 2mm in height you can print the last bit of his nose in a different colour.

Removing 'Mouse-ears'

These should only be 0.2mm thick so should be easy to remove with a pair of cable clippers.

Attaching to your card

I used 2 small glue dots to hold the print onto the front of the card. Inside the card I printed out tone001 great card insert design. I have included a copy with the design files, which has been edited so that you can print straight away onto A4 paper giving your 2 A6 card inserts.

Assembling the Reindeer

I would recommend including instructions in with your card.
This design will feel a bit looser that the original so some glue may help.

author: IdefixRC

title: MPSM Bed Leveling Utility
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a quick Gcode script for bed leveling on the Monoprice Select Mini. It finds home then steps through 5 positions, waiting for 5(or 2) seconds at each spot to test the clearance. The position it steps through are: Front Left (5,5), Back Left (5,115), Back Right (115,115), Front Right (115,5), and Center (60,60).

There are two versions:
Utility_Bed_Leveling.gcode (5s pause and 80mm/s movement)
Utility_Bed_Leveling_Quick_2s.gcode (2s pause and 100mm/s movement)

To use this script, first make sure there's no filament on the outside of your nozzle. Then put a piece of A4 paper on the build plate. Run the print, and at each of the 5 locations test the fit by trying to slide the paper around. Then after all 5 positions have been done, adjust the four corners. Then run it again and repeat until you're happy with the fit.

I like to adjust the fit so that there is definitely some resistance when moving the paper around but not so much that it leaves an obvious mark/gouge on the paper. But the exact fit will depend on how thick your paper is.

To adapt this to other printers/configurations you will have to change the 5 positions to correspond to your build volume and screw locations. Ex: "G1 X5 Y5; (Position 1)" moves to x=5mm and y=5mm. You will also have to check the Gcode variant that your printer runs and check that all the commands are supported. You can also adjust the pause time by changing the delay in the pause commands. Ex: "G4 P5000; (Pause 1)" Pauses for 5000 miliseconds. You can change the movement speed by changing the feed rate set at the beginning. Ex "G1 F4800 Z1;" Sets the feed rate to 4800mm/min before issuing the first move command.

Happy Printing!

comments.text: Does the code preheat the bed and hotend?
comments.author: jorgeluispena

comments.text: Glad you found the answer. This script is specifically meant to be quick, so you can run it multiple times in a row, making minute adjustments each time. Anytype of pre-heat would drastically increase the run time of the script. If you want the bed hot for the calibration, I recommend preheating the bed separately so that it stays hot while you make adjustments between runs.
comments.author: jorgeluispena

comments.text: Thanks for your answer. I agree with your assessment, at least for the Mini is easy to preheat the bed and nozzle, and then run multiple times this code.
comments.author: wileykyoto

comments.text: Yeah, it definitely makes quick work of calibration without risking damage to the drivers. Hope it works for you!
comments.author: jorgeluispena

author: wileykyoto

description.text:
This is a 1/32 scale interpretation of a Terrier locomotive. It is based on the drawing of the Terrier locomotive, "Bodiam" by Leslie Darbyshire on the Colonel Stephens Society's website:
http://colonelstephenssociety.co.uk/onewebmedia/KESR%20loco%20Bodiam%20(1)%20WM.jpg
The image is used with permission.

It is relatively small loco anyway, and looks small compared to G scale (circa 1/22 ) locos etc.
I have interpreted the drawing in making the model, and have tried to make it easy to print.
I have not included details like the "proper" hook connectors on the buffers. There are some alternate bodies included with various bits of detail. Some Terriers have horizontal pipes from the tanks to the funnel box. These are difficult to print unless the whole lot is printed together, when it becomes difficult to remove support structures inside.
The "Short Frame" is NOT scale length, but has been reduced to allow the frame to print as a single part on 200mm print beds. Everything else is smaller and should also print on 200mm beds.

The design uses m3 sleeved inserts in the body parts and wheels to take 8mm long M3 hex head screws to hold the parts together. It uses two "arduino smart Car Robot Plastic Tire Wheel with DC 3-6v Gear Motor" - be careful to get the ones with twin shafts, and not the one with a shaft on only one side.
There is a slot in the body to take the slide switch on the "RC ESC 20A Brush Motor Speed Controller ". There is room for the controller, an RC rx and a 1000mAh 2S lipo in the main body. Alternatively, you can use a Wemos ESP8266 with sound card and (and the same RC motor controller) to get a DCC controlled loco with sound. (see https://github.com/dagnall53/ESPMQTTRocnetSound)
The latest version of the software now can chuff and toot at the same time: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Pg5r6MZDhww

There is a video of some tests of the spring concept here: https://youtu.be/I7FIhVYsUMA

The early F360 design process is shown here: https://youtu.be/74LDF40UaGs but a lot has changed between that video and the current design.

The body and frame are screwed together with M3 8mm screws and 4mm M3 sleeved insert holes,(to total 4 for the smoke box to hold it down) and the Buffers beams are screwed on using two 1.8mm by 12mm screws each.
4 more 1.8mm dia 12mm long screws hold down the cab top.
The steps need to be glued on,

Parts list:
M3 8mm bolts, 16 needed.
1.812mm screws, 8 needed
3mm shaft, 51mm long 1 needed
3mm7mm*3mm Ballraces, 2 needed.
Motors: 2 needed
Electronics:
10A RC Brushed ESC
1500mAh 2S lipo +Extension cable for LIPO charge socket (to make charging available from rear bunker)
Then:
RC Receiver
or:
Wemos D1 mini +
Adafruit MAX98357 I2S Class-D Mono Amp
40 mm loudspeaker

I painted my body matt black
To finish it off I added some 0.7mm brass wire handrails and some Slaters 7951L - 7mm - 12 x 3.2mm Brass Handrail Knobs.
I also printed some BR crests and numbers and pasted these on, as well as printing some coal on card to cover the electronics in the coal bunker.

WARNING: MAKE sure the screws connecting the con rod to the wheel are well "secured with Loktite screw lock (or similar) and well secured before testing the motors. IF NOT, one side WILL tighten up and lock the con rod, either breaking it, or putting the wheel sides out of alignment. I have done this too many times now and need to be more patient!

Notes:

Printlarge parts using PLA, as they warped when I attempted prints in ABS.
0.2mm layers, 0.4mm nozzle.

This was designed in Fusion 360, by adding a canvas, making it the correct scale, and then building a sketch by tracing the key features.
I initially used "save history" and then played back the design sequence and video it.
Later in the project I made some big changes, (for example rotating one of the motors), and detail changes to the fixing screws etc.
My initial wheels, as in this video, needed to be redesigned as the con rod hit the frame,

The real loco has smooth sides, but I added some "side features" like a frame and welding features to add some interest. For purists there is stl without these features.

remixed_from.author: adafruit
remixed_from.title: Adafruit Pi Box - Enclosure for Raspberry PiÂ® Computers

description.text:
So there are plenty of cases out there for purchase, however, when we found one that we wanted in particular it was out of stock.  So we took it upon ourselves to try to make the case we wanted on our Replicator.
This case is based on the acrylic laser cut case by Adafruit.  Actually it is their laser cut file extruded 1/8" (3mm) to match the thickness of acrylic the design is based upon.

So just download the files and print! You will have to print case-c.stl twice to get the top and bottom.
Oh and you might be thinking why did we break the parts up into three files? So that if something happened during a print we would not have to start over from scratch.
You will have to do a little filing of the tabs to get them to fit in the slots but the case does work.  I have had the Raspberry Pi on in the case for several hours while working on it and have not had any issues.  It doesn't overheat or anything like that, but my Pi isn't overclocked or anything. So we can't make any promises.
Hanger for your stuff.

Muy buenas CMakers!,

Para la realización de este mando hemos utilizado los siguientes materiales:

Madera MDF de 1 cm de grosor: 1 cm o 0,5 cm.Necesitaréis un tablero de 800 mm x 400 mm.

Kit de botonera, mando y cableado: Nosotros seleccionamos un kit del fabricante XCSOURCE, que tiene una muy buena calidad/precio. Viene con todo lo necesario para que su montaje sobre nuestro mando sea muy fácil.

Una vez tengamos todo el material disponible, lo primero que tenemos que hacer es cortar todas las partes del mando. Como desde Carácter Maker nos encanta facilitar las cosas a nuestros CMakers, tenéis los planos de corte en formato DXF y STL.

Con el fichero en .DXF podéis imprimirlo en papel para haceros una plantilla, y luego cortarlo con herramientas manuales como sierras etc.., aunque recomendamos cortarlo en una cortadora láser, ya que en media hora lo tenéis hecho.

Para facilitar aún más vuestro trabajo, hemos incluido un archivo en formato .rld. Este archivo se abre con un programa llamado RDWorks (de descarga gratuita) que es utilizado por multitud de cortadoras láser. Está programado con los parámetros necesarios para que el corte y el grabado salga correctamente, aunque recomendamos que lo revise el técnico de turno ya que cada máquina es diferente. En concreto nosotros lo hemos cortado con una cortadora de 80W de potencia.

Una vez tenemos todas las piezas cortadas, el montaje no puede ser más fácil. En los puertos de arriba de la placa que véis en la foto conectaremos los cables que salen de cada botón. El color negro significa tierra y el rojo potencia. Cuando conectéis los cables a los botones, no importa que color conectéis a cada pata del botón. El puerto del joystick se conecta en el puerto de la izquierda y el puerto usb en el derecho.

Una vez todo montado y conectado sólo nos queda conectar el usb a nuestro ordenador, configurarlo en windows y....¡ a jugar!. Cuando diseñamos el mando queríamos que fuera fácil de abrir y cerrar la tapa, ya que si metemos dentro una raspberry, conectamos el usb a ella y sacamos por detrás un cable HDMI y la alimentación de la raspberry, ¡tenemos una máquina arcade pórtatil!.

This is a modified version of popemadmitch's Parametric Spool Adaptor allowing customization of more dimensions and using Thingiverse's integrated customization app.

The default dimensions are for a Digistruct spool with an 85mm (!!) inner diameter. I needed to mount it horizontally so Digistruct's adaptors on Pinshape.com were unsuitable because they do not have a flange.

Update: actually the digistruct spools are tapered, 85mm on one side and ~82mm on the other. So I had to print two short adaptors

A handle for some bigger things.

Uploading here in order to share with others I work with. We recently moved into a new office space and the door handles are pretty obnoxious. These simply create a sturdy cover for the part of the door handle we most use and that is also most painful due to sharp corners and heavy doors.

There are two handles/grips. The square one is pretty easy to print, but I recommend going upside down with it. I printed with 2mm supports which gave a nice clean line to the clip edges at the bottom. I sliced the sphere in half and printed that one upside down as well so I had a nice flat surface to print from. I used the same supports on both.

These are obviously for our specific door handles consisting of square tubing sections. Most handles are 32mm and 38.5mm, and these grips fit those handles.

title: Monoprice Maker Select Plus Lighting Bracket

description.text:
This is a design for a track and clips that hold a standard LED strip light to the RepRap Z brace kit for the MP Select Plus. I used 24v LED strip light so that I didn't have to use an external power supply and could hook directly in the extra terminals on the printers internal power supply. All parts are press fit so it does not require any fasteners or glue. I chose to drill a hole in the frame of the base to add a power switch, but that is an option modification.

Print 2 Tracks and 8 Clips

The LED strip is used in 10mm wide and can be found here.

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B071KDT15B/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

The Z Brace Kit can be found here.

https://reprapchampion.com/products/z-brace-frame-support-kit-for-wanhao-duplicator-i3-and-monoprice-maker-select-v1-v2-and-v2-1
